title: Equations with one rational expression (advanced)
description: Sal solves the following equation by first simplifying the rational expression: x^2-(x^2-4)/(x-2)=4.

title: Linear vs. exponential growth: from data
description: Sal constructs functions that model the growth of trees over time. To do that, he identifies which growth is linear and which is exponential.

title: Justifying the logarithm properties
description: Study the proofs of the logarithm properties: the product rule, the quotient rule, and the power rule.

title: Linear vs. exponential growth: from data (example 2)
description: Sal constructs a function that models cooling water. To do that, he decides whether the function is linear or exponential.

title: Equations with one rational expression (advanced)
description: Solve equations that have one rational expression whose numerator and denominator are polynomial expressions.

title: Even & odd polynomials
description: Sal analyzes three different polynomials to see if they are even, odd, or neither.

title: The change of base formula for logarithms
description: Learn how to rewrite any logarithmic expression in a different base. For example, rewrite log_2(3) as ln(3)/ln(2). This is very helpful for evaluating logarithms with a calculator, which only evaluates base-10 and base-e logarithms.

title: Linear vs. exponential growth: from data
description: Given a table with values of two quantities over time, determine whether the quantities form grow linearly or exponentially.

title: Equations with rational expressions
description: Sal solves (x²-10x+21)/(3x-12)=(x-5)/(x-4), which has one real solution and one extraneous solution.

title: Symmetry of polynomials
description: Learn how to determine if a polynomial function is even, odd, or neither.

title: Evaluating logarithms: change of base rule
description: Sal approximates log₅(100) by rewriting it as log(100)/log(5) using the change of base rule, then evaluates with a calculator.

title: Making an offer on a home
Magnitude of vectors
description: Find the magnitude of a vector given in component form.

title: Comparing growth of exponential & quadratic models
description: Sal discusses two functions that model the shipment rate of cars. One function is quadratic and the other is exponential. Which one will eventually exceed the other?

title: Logarithm change of base rule intro
description: Learn how to rewrite any logarithm using logarithms with a different base. This is very useful for finding logarithms in the calculator!

title: Even & odd polynomials
description: Given the formula of a polynomial function, determine whether that function is even, odd, or neither.

title: Equations with two rational expressions
description: Solve advanced rational equations with multiple expressions.

title: Evaluate logarithms: change of base rule
description: Evaluate any logarithm in a calculator with the use of the change of base formula. Example: Evaluate log₅(100).

title: Direct and inverse variation
description: Learn about direct and inverse variation, which are two types of relationships between two quantities. Direct variation is simply a proportional relationship, but inverse variation is more complicated and interesting. Gain some experience with it before we dive deeper into the world of rational functions.

title: Intro to direct & inverse variation
description: Sal explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.

title: Using the logarithm change of base rule
description: Sal rewrites logarithmic expressions like 1/(logₐ4) or logₐ(16)*log₂(a) using the change of base rule.

title: Recognizing direct & inverse variation
description: Sal gives many examples of two-variable equations where the variables vary directly, inversely, or neither.

title: Use the logarithm change of base rule
description: Find the logarithmic variable expression that is equivalent to a given logarithmic expression.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Learn about radians, which are the official unit of measurement for angles in algebra (in contrast to degrees, which are used in geometry).

title: Recognize direct & inverse variation
description: Given a few two-variable equations, find those that show direct or inverse variation.

title: Interpreting equations graphically
description: Sal interprets the intersection point of the graphs of functions f and g as the solution of the equation f(x)=g(x).

title: Proof of the logarithm change of base rule
description: Sal proves the logarithmic change of base rule, logₐ(b)=logₓ(b)/logₓ(a).

title: Recognizing direct & inverse variation: table
description: Sal is given a table with a few values of the variables x and y, and determines whether the variables vary directly or inversely.

title: Interpreting equations graphically (example 2)
description: Sal finds the coordinates of points on a graph that are solutions to a given equation.

title: Logarithm properties review
description: Review the logarithm properties and how to apply them to solve problems.

title: Inverse variation word problem: string vibration
description: Sal models a context about lengths of strings and the frequency of their vibrations! with an inverse variation equation.

title: Interpret equations graphically
description: Practice the connection between the graphical representation of equations and their algebraic solutions.

title: Solving exponential equations with logarithms
description: Learn how to solve any exponential equation by using logarithms. For example, solve 2^x=3 by calculating log_2(3).

title: Solving equations graphically (1 of 2)
description: Sal solves the equation e^x=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)] by considering the graphs of y=e^x and y=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)].

title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms: base-10
description: Sal solves the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.

title: End behavior of rational functions
description: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave as x approaches positive or negative infinity. This gets interesting Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

title: End behavior of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes the end behavior of several rational functions, that together cover all cases types of end behavior.

title: Solving equations graphically (2 of 2)
description: Sal solves the equation e^x=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)] by considering the graphs of y=e^x and y=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)].

title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms
description: Learn how to solve any exponential equation of the form a⋅b^(cx)=d. For example, solve 6⋅10^(2x)=48.

title: Tau versus pi
description: Why Tau might be a better number to look at than Pi

title: ROA discussion 2
description: More on the return on asset discussion.

title: EBITDA
description: Review of Enterprise Value and comparing it to EBITDA

title: Wealth destruction 2
description: How bubbles destroy wealth.

title: Arbitrage basics
description: Arbitrage Basics

title: Fed open market operations
description: Fed Open Market Operations

title: Credit default swaps
description: Introduction to credit default swaps

title: Carry trade basics
description: The mechanics of the carry trade

title: Radian angles & quadrants
description: Sal determines the quadrant at which a ray falls after a rotation by a certain measure of radians.

title: Solving equations graphically
description: Learn a clever method for approximating the solution of any equation.

title: End behavior of rational functions
description: Given a rational function, determine how it behaves as x approaches +∞ or -∞.

title: Solve exponential equations using logarithms: base-10 and base-e
description: Solve exponential equations that have 10 or e at the base of the exponential term.

title: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are extended to all real numbers using algebra. Start solving simple problems that involve this new definition of the trigonometric functions.

title: Solve equations graphically
description: Solve advanced and complicated equations using the power of graphs.

title: Unit circle
description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms: base-2
description:
We can use logarithms to solve *any* exponential equation of the form a⋅bᶜˣ=d. For example, this is how you can solve 3⋅10²ˣ=7:
1. Divide by 3: 10²ˣ=7/3
2. Use the definition of logarithm: 2x=log(7/3)
3. Divide by 2: x=log(7/3)/2 Now you can use a calculator to find the solution of the equation as a rounded decimal number
​

title: Quadratic systems: no solution
description: Sal solves a system of two quadratic equations algebraically and finds the system has no solutions. He then graphs the equations to show that this is true.

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

title: Graphing rational functions according to asymptotes
description: Sal analyzes the function f(x)=(3x^2-18x-81)/(6x^2-54) and determines its horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities.

title: Graph of y=tan(x)
description: Sal draws the graph of the tangent function based on the unit circle definition of the function.

title: Graphs of exponential functions
description: Learn about the graphs of advanced exponential functions of the form y=a*b^(x+c)+d.

title: Discontinuities of rational functions
description: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave when their denominator is equal to zero. This gets interesting when vertical asymptotes are involved! Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

title: Systems of quadratic equations
description: Learn how to solve systems of two equations in two variables, where at least one of the equations is quadratic.

title: Discontinuities of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes two rational functions to find their vertical asymptotes & removable discontinuities. He distinguishes those from the zeros of the functions.

title: Solve exponential equations using logarithms: base-2 and other bases
description: Solve exponential equations that have 2 or other numbers at the base of the exponential term.

title: The trig functions & right triangle trig ratios
description: Sal shows how, for acute angles, the two different definitions of the trigonometric values (SOH CAH TOA and the unit circle definition) result in the same values.

title: Quadratic systems: graphical solution
description: Sal solves a system of a quadratic equation and a linear equation by graphing both equations and looking for their intersections, and then checks the solution algebraically.

title: Rational function points of discontinuity
description: Given a rational function, sort given input values according to zeros, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities.

title: Trig unit circle review
description: Review the unit circle definition of the trigonometric functions.

title: Quadratic systems: algebraic solution
description: Sal solves a system of two quadratic equations that are solved for y by substituting the expression from one equation for y in the other equation.

title: Analyzing vertical asymptotes of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes the behavior of q(x)=(x²+3x+2)/(x+3) around its vertical asymptote at x=-3.

title: Exponential model word problem: medication dissolve
description: Sal solves an exponential equation in order to answer a question about an exponential model.

title: Graph of y=sin(x)
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).

title: Analyze vertical asymptotes of rational functions
description: Given the formula of a rational function, determine how it behaves around its vertical asymptote.

title: Exponential model word problem: bacteria growth
description: Sal evaluates an exponential function at a specific value in order to answer a question about an exponential model.

title: Quadratic systems: both variables are squared
description: Sal solves the system y=0.5x and 2x^2-y^2=7.

title: Graphs of rational functions
description: Combine your knowledge of intercepts, horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities, in order to analyze entire graphs of rational functions!

description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(ax^m+bx+12)/(cx^m+dx+12) based on its y-intercept.

title: Symmetry of algebraic models

title: Transforming exponential graphs

title: Amplitude of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Analyzing an elaborate rational expression to determine what's bigger: the value of that expression at some unknown c, or the number of times the expression is equal to 0? This is algebraic reasoning at its best!

title: Quadratic inequality word problem
description: Sal models a context that concerns a candy vending machine. The model turns out to be a quadratic inequality.

title: Period of sinusoidal functions
description: Learn about the period of sinusoidal functions: how it relates to extremum points and the midline, and how to find it from the formula of the function. For example, find the period of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

title: Period of sinusoidal functions from graph

title: Introduction to conic sections
description: Conic sections are formed when you intersect a plane with a cone. In this tutorial, you will learn more about what makes conic sections special.

title: Equations & inequalities word problems
description: Construct an equation or an inequality that model a given context. Modeling expressions can be quadratic, rational, or exponential.

title: Intro to conic sections
description: Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.

title: Period of sinusoidal functions from equation
description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its period.

title: Manipulating formulas: perimeter
description: Sal rewrites the formula for the perimeter of a rectangle so it is solved for width.

title: Midline, amplitude, and period review
description: Review the basic features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, and period.

description: Learn how to draw the graph of sinusoidal functions. For example, draw the graph of f(x)=-2*cos(πx)-7.

description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).

title: Summation notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Graph sinusoidal functions
description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function of the form a*f(bx)+d, draw its graph.

title: Features of a circle from its graph
description: Given the graph of a circle, find its center and radius.

title: Summation notation intro
description: Evaluate expressions that use sigma notation to make sure you understand what sigma notation means.

title: Introduction to economics
description: This tutorial (that only has one video) is an overview of what economics is.  In particular it will tell you the difference between microeconomics (the subject you're in right now) and macroeconomics.  Really good first watch to give you some context on the world of economics.

title: Constructing sinusoidal functions
description: Learn how to find the formula of a sinusoidal function from its graph or a few selected features. Model real-world situations with sinusoidal functions.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

title: Sinusoidal function from graph
description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.

title: Arithmetic series intro
description: Sal explains the formula for the sum of a finite arithmetic series

title: The demand curve
description: You've probably heard of supply and demand.  Well, this tutorial focuses on the demand part.  All else equal, do people want more or less of something if the price goes down (what would you do)? Not only will you get an intuition for the way we typically depict a demand curve, you'll get an understanding for what might shift it.

title: Arithmetic series formula
description: The sum of the first n terms in an arithmetic sequence is (n/2)⋅(a₁+aₙ). It is called the arithmetic series formula. Learn more about it here.

title: Worked example: arithmetic series (sigma notation)
description: Sal evaluates the arithmetic series Σ(2k+50) for k=1 to 550. He does that using the arithmetic series formula (a₁+aₙ)*n/2.

title: Modeling with sinusoidal functions
description: Given the description of a real-world relationship, find the sinusoidal function that models it.

title: Worked example: arithmetic series (sum expression)
description: Sal evaluates the arithmetic sum (-50)+(-44)+(-38)+...+2044. He does that by finding the number of terms and using the arithmetic series formula (a₁+aₙ)*n/2.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

title: Worked example: arithmetic series (recursive formula)
description: Sal evaluates the sum of the first 650 terms in the sequence defined recursively as {aᵢ=aᵢ₋₁+11, a₁=4}. He does that by finding the 650th term and using the arithmetic series formula (a₁+aₙ)*n/2.

title: Price elasticity
description: You're familiar with supply and demand curves already.  In this tutorial we'll explore what implications their steepness (or lack of) implies.  Price elasticity is a measure of how sensitive something is to price.

title: Arithmetic series worksheet
description: Try a few problems where you'll be asked to evaluate finite arithmetic series.

title: The supply curve
description: Now we'll focus on the "supply" part of supply and demand.  Supply curves (as we typically depict them) come out of the idea that producers will make more if they get paid more.

title: Arithmetic series
description: Practice evaluating arithmetic series using the formula (n/2)⋅(a₁+aₙ).

title: Focus and directrix of a parabola
description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the focus) and a line (called the directrix). In this tutorial you will learn about the focus and the directrix, and how to find the equation of a parabola given its focus and directrix.

title: Proof of finite arithmetic series formula
description: Watch Sal prove the expression for the sum of all positive integers up to and including n.

title: Intro to focus & directrix
description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.

title: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios
description: Meet your new best friends: sine, cosine, and tangent.

title: CPI index
description: Discussion of inflation, the CPI index and owners' equivalent rent.

title: Estate tax introduction
description: Overview of the estate tax

title: Market capitalization
description: Market versus book value of equity

title: Amortization
description: Introduction to amortization

title: Equation of a parabola from focus & directrix
description: The equation of a parabola is derived from the focus and directrix, and then the general formula is used to solve an example.

title: Equation of a parabola from focus & directrix
description: Given the focus and the directrix of a parabola, find its equation.

title: Market equilibrium
description: You understand demand and supply.  This tutorial puts it all together by thinking about where the two curves intersect.  This point represents the equilibrium price and quantity which is, in an ideal world, where the market would transact.

title: Focus & directrix of a parabola from equation
description: Given the parabola equation y-23/4=-1/3(x-1)^2, Sal finds the parabola's focus and directrix using the general formula for a parabola whose focus is (a,b) and directrix is y=k.

title: Parabola focus & directrix review
description: Review your knowledge of the focus and directrix of parabolas.

title: Elasticity in the long run and short run
description: The elasticity of supply or demand can vary based on the length of time you care about.

title: Elasticity and tax revenue
description: Read about how elasticity affects tax revenue.

title: What drives oil prices
description: This tutorial tries to address a very important question in the real world--what drives oil prices?  And we will do it using the tools of the supply and demand curves.

title: Comparative advantage and gains from trade
description:
Should you try to produce everything yourself or only what you are best at and trade for everything else?  What if you're better than your trading partners at everything?  

This tutorial focuses on comparative advantage, specialization and gains from trade with a microeconomic lens.

title: Marginal utility and budget lines
description: In this tutorial we look at the utility of getting one more of something and put numbers to it.  We then use this to construct a budget line and think about indifference curves.

title: The law of sines
description: Learn about the Law of sines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

title: Sine and cosine of complementary angles
description: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90°.

title: The inverse trigonometric functions
description: Learn about the inverse functions of sine, cosine, and tangent, and how they are defined even though the functions are not really invertible. These functions will be very helpful when you will solve trigonometric equations.

title: Intro to arcsine
description: Sal introduces arcsine, which is the inverse function of sine, and discusses its principal range.

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

title: Intro to arctangent
description: Sal introduces arctangent, which is the inverse function of tangent, and discusses its principal range.

title: Intro to arccosine
description: Sal introduces arccosine, which is the inverse function of cosine, and discusses its principal range.

title: Consumer and producer surplus
description: Many times, the equilibrium price is lower than the highest price some folks are willing to pay.  For all consumers, this is called consumer surplus.  Similarly, the price might be higher than the minimum price at which some are willing to produce.  For all the producers, this is called producer surplus.  This tutorial covers them both with an emphasis on the visual.

title: Elasticity in areas other than price
description: Elasticity also applies in labor markets and in financial capital markets

title: Finite geometric series
description: Whether you are computing mortgage payments or calculating how many users your website will have after a few years,  geometric  series show up in life far more than you imagine.  This tutorial will review all the important concepts and more!

title: Geometric series intro
description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn more about it here.

title: Production possibilities frontier
description: This tutorial goes back to the basics.  You are a hunter-gatherer with only so much time to hunt or gather.  How do you allocate your time and energy to maximize your happiness?  This is what we try to understand through our study of the production possibilities frontier and opportunity cost.

title: Geometric series with sigma notation
description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn about geometric series and how they can be written in general terms and using sigma notation.

title: Economic profit and opportunity cost
description: Economic profit and accounting profit are two different things (the difference being that economic profit takes into account opportunity cost).  Confused?  This tutorial lays it all out with the example of a restaurant.

title: Deadweight loss
description: We can often lose economic efficiency because of things like price floors, ceilings and taxes.  This loss in surplus (people who have more marginal benefit than marginal cost are not buying or people who have more marginal cost than benefit are buying) is called deadweight loss.

title: Finite geometric series formula
description: The finite geometric series formula is a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r). In this video, Sal gives a pretty neat justification as to why the formula works.

title: Worked example: finite geometric series (sigma notation)
description: Sal evaluates the geometric series Σ2(3ᵏ) for k=0 to 99 using the finite geometric series formula a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r).

title: Worked examples: finite geometric series
description: Sal evaluates three geometric series (defined in various ways) using the finite geometric series formula a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r).

title: Average costs (ATC, MC) and marginal revenue (MR)
description: In this tutorial, Sal uses the example of an orange juice business to help us understand the ideas of average total cost (ATC), marginal cost (MC) and marginal revenue (MR).  We then use this understanding to answer the age-old question, "how much orange juice should I produce?"  Finally, we use these ideas to construct a long-run supply curve.  A must watch if you're interested in making juice!

title: Finite geometric series
description: Evaluate finite geometric series given in sigma notation, recursively, or explicitly.

title: Finite geometric series applications
description: Apply what you've learned about geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.

title: Public goods and externalities
description: In many scenarios thinking only about producers' marginal cost or consumers' marginal benefit does not fully capture *all* of the costs or benefits from the production/use of a product.  In this tutorial, we explore these externalities (negative and positive ones) to think a bit deeper about ways to maximize total surplus not just for producers and consumers, but for society as a whole.

title: Finite geometric series word problems
description: Understanding and solving problems with the formula for a finite geometric series

title: Average fixed, variable and marginal costs
description: Using a spreadsheet, Sal walks through an example of average costs per line of code as a firm hires more engineers.  Really good primer to understand what average fixed costs, average variable costs, average total costs (ATC) and average marginal costs (MC) are (and how they are calculated).

title: Perfect competition
description: This tutorial looks at markets that are deemed to have "perfect competition."  This means that there are many players with identical products, no barriers to entry, no advantage for existing players and good pricing information.  Few to no real market completely matches this theoretical ideal, but many are close.  Even the example we use in this tutorial (the airline industry) isn't quite perfect (you should think about why).

title: Labor and marginal product revenue
description: Constructing a demand curve for an individual firm by thinking about how much increment benefit they get from an incremental employee (marginal product of labor (MPL) and marginal product revenue (MPR).  We later think about how we can add these "demand" curves to construct a "demand" curve for the market for labor in this industry.

title: Bonus articles: Pollution as a negative externality
description: Pollution and environmental regulation are rich examples of negative externalities and the tradeoffs we face when dealing with them.

title: Price discrimination
description: This short tutorial explores how a wine business can utilize first-degree price discrimination to maximize economic profit (it uses many of the ideas we've explored in the rest of this tutorial).

title: Nash equilibrium
description:
If you haven't watched the movie "A Beautiful Mind", you should.  It is about John Nash (played by Russell Crowe) who won the Nobel Prize in economics for his foundational contributions to game theory.  This is what this tutorial is about.

Nash put some structure around how players in a "game" can optimize their outcomes (if the movie is to be fully believed, this insight struck him when he realized that if all his friends hit on the most pretty girl, he should hit on the second-most pretty one).  In this tutorial, we use the classic "prisoner's dilemma" to highlight this concept.

title: Monopoly
description:
No, we aren't talking about the board game although the game does try to approximate what this tutorial is about--notice that you can charge more rent at either Boardwalk or Park Place if you own both (you have a "monopoly" in the navy blue market).

The opposite of perfect competition is when you have only one firm operating.  This tutorial explores what this firm would do to maximize economic profit.

title: Why parties in a cartel will cheat
description:
You know what Nash equilibrium is (from the other tutorial).  Now we apply it to a scenario that is fairly realistic--parties to a cartel cheating.

A cartel is a group of actors that agree (sometimes illegally) to coordinate their production/pricing to maximize their collective economic profit.  What we will see, however, is that this is not a "Pareto optimal" state and they will soon start producing more than agreed on.

title: Bonus articles: Innovation as a positive externality
description: Innovation often benefits many people, not just the person or company that innovated.

title: Between perfect competition and monopoly
description: Most markets sit somewhere in-between perfect competition and monopolies.  This tutorial explores some of those scenarios--from monopolistic competition to oligopolies and duopolies.

title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.

title: Solving for an angle in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Learn how to find an acute angle in a right triangle when given two side lengths.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Learn about radians, which are the official unit of measurement for angles in algebra (in contrast to degrees, which are used in geometry).

title: Modeling with right triangles
description: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

title: Introduction to amplitude, midline, and extrema of sinusoidal functions
description: Learn about very important features of sinusoidal functions: the amplitude and the midline. Learn how they relate to the extremum points of the function.

title: Trigonometric ratios and similarity
description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: Learn about the ingenious way in which we define the trigonometric functions for any real number.

title: Finding amplitude and midline of sinusoidal functions from their formulas
description: Learn how to find the amplitude and the midline of the graph of a sinusoidal function from its formula. For example, find the amplitude and the midline of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

title: Sine & cosine of complementary angles
description: Learn about the relationship between the sine & cosine of complementary angles, which are angles who together sum up to 90°.

title: Period of sinusoidal functions
description: Learn about the period of sinusoidal functions: how it relates to extremum points and the midline, and how to find it from the formula of the function. For example, find the period of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

title: Evaluate inverse trig functions
description: Given a sine, cosine, or tangent value, find the principle angle who has this value. In other words, find the arcsine, arccosine, or arctangent of that value.

title: Basic trigonometric identities
description: Learn about very useful trigonometric identities that arise by considering different properties of the unit circle definition.

title: Trigonometric ratios of special triangles
description: Learn to find the sine, cosine, and tangent of 45-45-90 triangles and also 30-60-90 triangles.

title: Trig ratios of special triangles
description: Learn to find the sine, cosine, and tangent of 45-45-90 triangles and also 30-60-90 triangles.

title: Domain & range of inverse tangent function
description: Sal finds the formula for the inverse function of g(x)=tan(x-3π/2)+6, and then determines the domain of that inverse function.

title: Introduction to the Pythagorean trigonometric identity
description: Learn about a very special trigonometric identity that follows from the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Using inverse trig functions with a calculator
description: Sal discusses the appropriate way to use the calculator in order to find an angle when its tangent value is given.

title: Intro to the Pythagorean trig identity
description: Sal introduces and proves the identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1, which arises from the Pythagorean theorem!

title: Inverse trigonometric functions review
description: Review your knowledge of the inverse trigonometric functions, arcsin(x), arccos(x), & arctan(x).

title: The reciprocal trigonometric ratios
description: Learn about the remaining three side ratios in a right triangle: the secant, the cosecant, and the cotangent.

title: Trigonometric values of special angles
description: Learn how to find the trigonometric values of some special angles without the use of a calculator.

title: Solving basic sinusoidal equations
description: Learn how to solve equations of the form sin(x)=d or cos(x)=d where d is any number. For example, solve sin(x)=0.6.

title: Reciprocal trig ratios
description: Learn how cosecant, secant, and cotangent are the reciprocals of the basic trig ratios: sine, cosine, and tangent.

title: Solving sinusoidal equations of the form sin(x)=d
description: Sal finds the expressions that together represent all possible solutions to the equation sin(x)=1/3.

title: Finding reciprocal trig ratios
description: Sal finds all six trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent, secant, cosecant, and cotangent) of an angle in a given right triangle.

title: Graph sinusoidal functions: phase shift
description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function of the form a*f(bx+c)+d, draw its graph.

title: Payday loans
description: How Payday lending works

title: Solving cos(θ)=1 and cos(θ)=-1
description: Sal solves the equations cos(θ)=1 and cos(θ)=-1 using the graph of y=cos(θ).

title: Using reciprocal trig ratios
description: Sal is given two sides in a right triangle and the cotangent of one of the angles, and he uses this information to find the missing side.

title: Constructing sinusoidal functions
description: Learn how to find the formula of a sinusoidal function from its graph or a few selected features. Model real-world situations with sinusoidal functions.

title: Solve sinusoidal equations (basic)
description: Solve equations of the form sin(x)=d or cos(x)=d where d is any number.

title: Reciprocal trig ratios
description: Understand the right triangle definition of sec, csc, and cot ratios.

title: Solving advanced sinusoidal equations
description: Learn how to solve equations of the form a*sin(bx+c)=d or a*cos(bx+c)=d where a, b, c, and d are any number. For example, solve 5*sin(2x-1)=3.

title: Trigonometric ratios review
description: Review all six trigonometric ratios: sine, cosine, tangent, cotangent, secant, & cosecant.

title: Solve sinusoidal equations
description: Solve equations of the form a*sin(bx+c)=d or a*cos(bx+c)=d where a, b, c, and d are any number.

title: Long live Tau
description: Watch videos by Sal and Vi that discuss the ongoing battle between the more popular Pi (π=3.14..) and its more qualified rival Tau (τ=6.28...).

title: Trig word problem: solving for temperature
description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by solving a sinusoidal equation.

title: Trig word problem: length of day (phase shift)
description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in the length of day by modeling it with a sinusoidal function that has a phase shift.

title: Sinusoidal models word problems
description: Solve word problems that involve real-world contexts that are modeled by sinusoidal functions.

title: Compound interest basics
description:
Interest is the basis of modern capital markets.  Depending on whether you are lending or borrowing, it can be viewed as a return on an asset (lending) or the cost of capital (borrowing).

This tutorial gives an introduction to this fundamental concept, including what it means to compound.  It also gives a rule of thumb that might make it easy to do some rough interest calculations in your head.

title: Pi is (still) wrong
description: Please excuse the simple math and spelling errors. You shouldn't believe anything I say without double-checking even at the best of times. Go here: http://tauday.com/ and here: http://www.math.utah.edu/~palais/pi.html Me: http://vihart.com

title: Modeling with sinusoidal functions: phase shift
description: Given the description of a real-world relationship, find the sinusoidal function that models it. The functions in this exercise have a phase (horizontal) shift.

title: Compound interest introduction
description: Learn about the basics of compound interest, with examples of basic compound interest calculations

title: Trigonometric equations review
description: Review your trigonometric equation skills by solving a sequence of equations in increasing complexity.

title: The rule of 72 for compound interest
description: Using the Rule of 72 to approximate how long it will take for an investment to double at a given interest rate

title: Introduction to the trigonometric angle addition identities
description: Learn about the trigonometric angle addition identities, which help us discuss the trig values of sums of angles in terms of the trig values of the individual angles. For example, we can express sin(x+y) in terms of sin(x), sin(y), cos(x), and cos(y).

title: Review of trig angle addition identities
description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b), sin(a-c), cos(a+b), cos(a-b), cos(2a), and sin(2a).

title: Interest basics
description: This is a good introduction to the basic concept of interest.  We will warn you that it is an older video so Sal's sound and handwriting weren't quite up to snuff then.

title: Using the cosine angle addition identity
description: Sal evaluates the cosine of the sum of 60° and another angle whose right triangle is given. To do this, he must use the cosine angle addition formula.

title: Inflation basics
description: $1 went a lot further in 1900 than today (you could probably buy a good meal for the family for $1 back then).  Why?  And how do we measure how much more expensive things have gotten (i.e., inflation)?

title: Using the cosine double-angle identity
description: Sal evaluates the cosine of twice an angle whose right triangle is given. To do this, he must use the cosine double-angle formula.

title: Home equity and personal balance sheets
description: This old and badly drawn tutorial covers a topic essential to anyone planning to not live in the woods -- your personal balance sheet.  Since homes are usually the biggest part of these personal balance sheets, we cover that too.

title: Credit cards and loans
description:
Most of us have borrowed to buy something.  Credit cards, in particular, can be quite convenient (but dangerous if not used in moderation).

This tutorial explains credit card interest, how credit card companies make money and a far more silly way of borrowing money called "payday" loans.

title: Using the trig angle addition identities
description: Find the trig values of sums of angles whose individual trig values are known.

title: Introduction to balance sheets
description: Using a home purchase to illustrate assets, liabilities and owner's equity.

title: What is inflation
description: The basics of what price inflation is and how the CPI-U is calculated

title: Annual percentage rate (APR) and effective APR
description: The difference between APR and effective APR

title: Proof of the sine angle addition identity
description: Sal proves the identity sin(x+y) = sin(x)*cos(y) + cos(x)*sin(y).

title: More on balance sheets and equity
description: What happens to equity when the value of the assets increase or decrease?

title: Institutional roles in issuing and processing credit cards
description: The institutions involved in processing your credit credit and how they relate to each other

title: Proof of the cosine angle addition identity
description: Sal proves the identity cos(x+y) = cos(x)*cos(y) - sin(x)*sin(y).

title: Home equity loans
description: Simple example of borrowing from equity to fuel consumption

title: Inflation scenarios
description: You know about inflation, but now want to look at how thing might play out in different scenarios.  This tutorial focuses on when inflation is "acceptable" and when it isn't (and the causes and repercussions).

title: Using trigonometric identities to solve problems
description: Learn about different ways in which trigonometric identities, such as the Pythagorean identity and the angle addition identities, can be used to solve problems.

title: Renting vs. buying a home
description:
Is it always better to buy than rent?  What if home prices go up dramatically and rents don't?  How can we compare home prices to rents to figure out what to do.

This older tutorial (low-res, bad handwriting) walks us through this.  It is about housing but similar thinking can be applied to any rent-vs-buy decision (spoiler alert, Sal did eventually buy a home).

title: Continuous compound interest and e
description: This is an older tutorial (notice the low-res, bad handwriting) about one of the coolest numbers in reality and how it falls out of our innate desire to compound interest continuously.

title: Finding trig values using angle addition identities
description: Sal finds the value of sin(7π/12) by rewriting it as sin(π/3+π/4) and then using the sine angle addition formula.

title: Find trig values using angle addition identities
description: Find the trigonometric values of various angles that (while they are not special angles) can be expressed as the sum or difference of special angles.

title: Is buying a home always better?
description: The math of renting vs. buying a home. Challenging the notion that it is always better to buy.

title: Real and nominal return
description: If the value of money is constantly changing, can we compare investment return in the future or past to that earned in the present?  This tutorial focuses on how to do this (another good tutorial to watch is the one on "present value").

title: Present value 3
description: What happens when we change the discount rate?

title: What happens when housing depreciates
description: Factoring in appreciation and depreciation into the rent vs. buy decision.

title: Using trig angle addition identities: finding side lengths
description: Sal is given a drawing with two triangles and some side lengths, and he uses the sine angle addition identity in order to find a missing side length.

title: Present value
description:
If you gladly pay for a hamburger on Tuesday for a hamburger today, is it equivalent to paying for it today?

A reasonable argument can be made that most everything in finance really boils down to "present value".  So pay attention to this tutorial.

title: Using trig angle addition identities: manipulating expressions
description: Sal is given that cos(2θ)=C and he uses the cosine double-angle identity in order to find an expression for sin(θ).

title: Renting vs. buying (detailed analysis)
description: Detailed analysis of the rent vs. buy decision.

title: Time value of money
description: Why when you get your money matters as much as how much money. Present and future value also discussed.

title: Mortgages
description: Most people buying a home need a mortgage to do so.  This tutorial explains what a mortgage is and then actually does some math to figure out what your payments are (the last video is quite mathy so consider it optional).

title: Capacity utilization and inflation
description: This tutorial starts with a very "micro" view of when firms decide to raise (or lower prices).  It then jumps back to the macro view to discuss how capacity utilization can impact prices.

title: Using trigonometric identities
description: Rewrite trigonometric expressions using the Pythagorean identity and other trigonometric identities.

title: Introduction to mortgage loans
description: Introduction to mortgage loans

title: Economics of a cupcake factory
description: Economics of a simple business leading up to a discussion on inflation/deflation.  Touching on income statements.

title: Trig identity reference
description: Look up AND understand all your favorite trig identities

title: Mortgage interest rates
description: Understanding how mortgage interest rates are quoted

title: Challenging trigonometry problems
description: See Sal solve a bunch of very challenging geometry and algebra problems that involve trigonometry.

title: Present value 4 (and discounted cash flow)
description: Lets change the discount rates depending on how far out the payments are.

title: Trig challenge problem: area of a triangle
description: Sal solves a very complicated geometrical trig problem that appeared as problem 11 in the 2003 AIME II exam.

title: Roth IRAs
description: Introduction to Roth IRA's

title: Defining average and instantaneous rates of change at a point
Cupcake economics 3
description: Using our spreadsheet to show why prices decrease when utilization is low and prices increase when utilization is high.

title: Inflation, deflation, and capacity utilization
description: A discussion of inflation and deflation

title: Trig challenge problem: area of a hexagon
description: Sal solves a very complicated geometrical trig problem that appeared as problem 14 in the 2003 AIME II exam.

title: Personal bankruptcy
description: Back in the day (like medieval Europe), you would actually be thrown in jail if you couldn't pay your debts (debtor's prison).  That seemed like a pretty awful thing to do (not to mention that lenders are much less likely to be paid by someone rotting in prison), so governments created an "out" called bankruptcy (which, as you'll see, is a pseudo-painful "reset" button on your finances).

title: Personal bankruptcy:  Chapters 7 and 13
description: Chapter 7 and Chapter 13 personal bankruptcy.

title: Trig challenge problem: cosine of angle-sum
description: Sal is given cos(θ) and cos(φ) and he finds cos(θ+φ). To do that, he must first find sin(θ) and sin(φ) using the Pythagorean identity.

title: Inflation, deflation, and capacity utilization 2
description: More on inflation and capacity utilization

title: Inflation and deflation 3: Obama stimulus plan
description: Is the stimulus large enough to offset the demand shock caused by the contraction in credit?  Will it lead to inflation?

title: Trig challenge problem: arithmetic progression
description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 29 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.

title: Deflation
description: Prices don't always go up.  They often go down.  This might seem like a good thing, but it could be disastrous for a modern economy is it goes too far.  This tutorial explains what deflation is, how it happens and what the effects of it might be.

title: Trig challenge problem: maximum value
description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 48 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.

title: Home buying process
description: Buying a home involves a lot more than writing a check and getting keys.  It could very well be the largest transaction that either the buyer or seller does in their life.  Because that, it is an involved process that can sometimes be confusing.  Whether we're talking title insurance, escrow, or contingencies, the goal of this tutorial is to demystify the process.

title: Personal taxes
description:
Benjamin Franklin (and several other writers/philosophers) tells us that "In this world nothing can be said to be certain, except death and taxes."  He's right.  

This tutorial focus on personal income tax.  Very important to watch if you ever plan on earning money (some of which the government will take for itself).

title: Trig challenge problem: multiple constraints
description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 47 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.

title: Basics of US income tax rate schedule
description: Understanding that a marginal tax rate does not apply to all of income

title: Tax deductions introduction
description: Understanding what a tax deduction is

title: Trig challenge problem: system of equations
description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 55 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.

title: AMT overview
description: Overview of what the Alternative Minimum Tax is and its purpose

title: Alternative minimum tax
description: The basics of the alternative minimum tax

title: Cash versus accrual accounting
description: Just keeping track of cash that goes in and out of a business doesn't always reflect what's going on.  This tutorial compares cash and accrual accounting.  Very valuable if you ever plan on starting or investing in any type of business (you might also discover a nascent passion for accounting)!

title: Introduction to stocks
description: Many people own stocks, but, unfortunately, most of them don't really understand what they own.  This tutorial will keep you from being one of those people (not keep you from owning stock, but keep you from being ignorant about your investments).

title: Calculating federal taxes and take home pay
Mutual funds and ETFs
description: If we're not in the mood to research and pick our own stocks, mutual funds and/or ETFs might be a good option.  This tutorial explains what they are and how they are different.

title: Accrual basis of accounting
description: Simple example of accrual accounting

title: Open-ended mutual fund (part 1)
description: Introduction to Open-Ended Mutual Funds

title: Shorting stock
description: Can you sell something that you borrowed from someone else?  Why, yes, you can and it is called "shorting".  Why would you do this?  Well, you can now make money if the price goes down.  Is this bad?  This tutorial has your answers.

title: Comparing accrual and cash accounting
description: Comparing Accrual and Cash Accounting

title: Open-end mutual fund redemptions (part 2)
description: Understanding the mechanics of an open end mutual fund a bit better

title: Three core financial statements
description:
Corporations use three financial statements to report what's going on: balance sheets, cash flow statements and income statements.  They can be derived from each other and each give a valuable lens on the operations and condition of a business.  

After you know the basics of accrual accounting (available in another tutorial), this tutorial will give you tools you need to responsibly understand any business.

title: Closed-end mutual funds
description: Comparing closed-end and open-ended mutual funds

title: Balance sheet and income statement relationship
description: Balance Sheet and Income Statement Relationship

title: Corporate taxation
description: In exchange for being treated as a person-like-legal entity (and the limited liability this gives for its owners), most corporations pay taxes.  This tutorial focuses on what corporations are, "double taxation" and a few ways that multinationals might try to get out of paying taxes.

title: Corporations and limited liability
description: Why people set up corporations

title: Exchange traded funds (ETFs)
description: Comparing ETF's,  open-end, and closed-end funds

title: Interpreting the Balance Sheet
description: Learn the differences between Assets and Liabilities, and how to calculate Total Equity.  Understand Balance Sheet items like Cash, Accounts Receivable, and Deferred Revenue.

title: Is short selling bad?
description: A discussion of the virtues and/or vices of short selling.

title: Interpreting the Income Statement
description: Interpreting the Income Statement

title: Is limited liability or double taxation fair?
description: Thinking about whether limited liability or double taxation is fair

title: Understanding company statements and capital structure
description:
If you understand what a stock is (also a good idea to look at the topic on accounting and financial statements), then you're ready to dig in a bit on a company's actual financials.

This tutorial does this to help you understand what the price of a company really is.

title: Gross and operating profit
description: Difference between gross profit, operating profit, and net income.

title: Retirement accounts: IRAs and 401ks
description: The government apparently wants us to save for retirement (not always obvious because it also wants us to spend as much as possible to pump the economy going into the next election cycle).  To encourage this, it has created some ways to save that avoid or defer taxes: IRAs and 401ks.

title: Basic cash flow statement
description: Using a cash flow statement to reconcile net income with change in cash

title: Transfer pricing and tax havens
description: How a corporation can set up a tax haven and use it through transfer pricing.

title: Basic capital structure differences
description: Understanding basic capital structure differences

title: Traditional IRAs

description: Introduction to Accounts Payable

title: Fair value accounting

title: Depreciation and amortization
description: How do you account for things that get "used up" or a cost that should be spread over time.  This tutorial has your answer.  Depreciation and amortization might sound fancy, but you'll hopefully find them to be quite understandable.

title: Banking and money
description:
We all use money and most of us use banks.  Despite this, the actual working of the banking system is a bit of a mystery to most (especially fractional reserve banking).

This older tutorial (bad handwriting and resolution) starts from a basic society looking to do more than barter and incrementally builds to a modern society with fraction reserve banking. Through this process, you will hopefully gain a deep understanding of how money and banking works in our modern world.

title: Expensing a truck leads to inconsistent performance
description: Expensing a truck leads to strange looking income statement

title: Corporate metrics and valuation
description:
Life is full of people who will try to convince you that something is a good or bad idea by spouting technical jargon.  Most of them have no idea what they are talking about.  Don't be one of those people or their victims when it comes to stocks.

From P/E rations to EV/EBITDA, we've got your back!

title: Life insurance
description: It is a bit of a downer to think about, but we are all going to die.  Do we care what happens to our loved ones? (If they really are "loved" then the answer is obvious).  This tutorial walks us through the options to insure our families against losing us.  The reason why we stuck it in the "investment vehicles" topic is because it can also be an investment that we can use before we die.

title: Banking 1
description: Introduction to how banks make money and the value they (potentially) add to society.

title: Hedge funds
description:
Hedge funds have absolutely nothing to do with shrubbery.  Their name comes from the fact that early hedge funds (and some current ones) tried to "hedge" their exposure to the market (so they could, in theory, do well in an "up" or "down" market as long as they were good at picking the good companies).  Today, hedge funds represent a huge class investment funds.  

They are far less regulated than, say, mutual funds.  In exchange for this, they aren't allowed to market or take investments from "unsophisticated" investors.  Some use their flexibility to mitigate risk, other use it to amplify it.

title: Banking 3: Fractional reserve banking

title: Put and call options
description:
Options allow investors and speculators to hedge downside (or upside).  It allows them to trade on a belief that prices will change a lot--just not clear about direction.  It allows them to benefit in any market (with leverage) if they speculate correctly.

This tutorial walks through option basics and even goes into some fairly sophisticated option mechanics.

When are you using capital to create more things (investment) vs. for consumption (we all need to consume a bit to be happy).  When you do invest, how do you compare risk to return?  Can capital include human abilities?

This tutorial hodge-podge covers it all.

You know that the Federal Reserve (or central banks in general) controls the money supply and short-term interest rates.  But how exactly do they do this.  Even more, how is "quantitative easing" different than regular open market operations.

This tutorial explains it all in the context of the Federal Reserves attempts to stave off deflation during the 2008-2012 recession.

title: Paulson bailout
description:
In the fall of 2008, it became clear that a cascade of bank failures was happening because of shoddy loans and exotic securities (both which fueled a now popping housing bubble).  In an attempt to avoid a depression, the Treasury Secretary (Hank Paulson) wanted to pour \$1 Trillion into the same banks that had created the mess.

This tutorial walks us through the beginnings of the mess and possible solutions.  Historical note: it was created as the crisis was unfolding.

The poop really started to hit the fan in the fall of 2008.  When the new administration took office in early 2009, the poop was still there.  This is tutorial explains an attempt--probably not a well thought out one--to clean the poop and slow the fan.

Videos on the Geithner Plan to solve the continuing banking crisis in early 2009.

title: Data inferences — Harder example
description:
Watch Sal work through a harder Data inferences problem. 

We make a confidence interval by starting with a sample result and adding and subtracting the margin of error. Consequently, the sample result is the exact middle of the interval. If we were to build a new interval based on the same data but with a reduced confidence level, the new interval would have the same center but a smaller margin of error. Here's a diagram illustrating this problem another way.
